abstract: Public sector jobs, long a path to middle class for black Americans, are becoming scarcer and more difficult to acquire; elimination of public jobs during Great Recession, as well as anti-government and anti-labor sentiments, have had particularly harsh effect on blacks, who hold public jobs at 30 percent higher rate than whites; shift endangers many of gains middle-class blacks have made in recent decades (Series: Shifting Middle).
lead_paragraph: As public sector employment, once a dependable pathway to success for many blacks, was cut in the downturn, African-American communities suffered an outsize toll.

headline.main: Public-Sector Jobs Vanish, Hitting Blacks Hard
